stories.text: He used lead and others have used iron. Hydrogen is different as it has no (mostly no) neutrons. Has anyone tried to make a balance like his with hydrogen liquid? Neutrons are assumed to not act at a distance. But probably only because of the extreme difficulty of getting a neutron to stay still, long enough to measure it's attractiveness to other particles at a distance. One neutron can attract to more than one proton.
stories.title: Ask HN: Has anyone tried the Cavendish balance experiment with hydrogen liquid?
